pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:2.1: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:5.1: 57. The training rule on holding a sunshade
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:6.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Bhagga country at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove, the deer park.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:6.2: At that time the monks from the group of six gave teachings to people holding a sunshade.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.1: The monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.3: “How can the monks from the group of six give teachings to people holding a sunshade?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.4: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.7: Foolish men, how can you give teachings to people holding a sunshade?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:7.9: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:8.1: ‘“I will not give teachings to anyone holding a sunshade,” this is how you should train.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:9.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:10.1: Soon afterwards, being afraid of wrongdoing, monks did not give teachings to sick people holding a sunshade.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:10.3: “How could the Sakyan ascetics not give teachings to someone who’s sick holding a sunshade?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:11.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:11.3: Soon afterwards he gave a teaching and addressed the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:11.4: “Monks, I allow you to give teachings to someone who’s sick holding a sunshade.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:11.5: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:12.1: ‘“I will not give teachings to anyone holding a sunshade who is not sick,” this is how you should train.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:13.2: there are three kinds of sunshade: the white sunshade; the reed sunshade; the leaf sunshade, either bound at the rim or bound at the ribs.

pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:15.2: if he teaches by the line, then for every line he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:15.3: If he teaches by the syllable, then for every syllable he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:15.4: One should not give teachings to anyone holding a sunshade who is not sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk57:15.5: If a monk out of disrespect gives teachings to someone holding a sunshade who is not sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
